Notes: Largest country in the world (10.995% of the world's land mass); its Asian portion makes it the largest country in Asia, and its European portion of roughly 3,960,000 km2 (1,530,000 sq mi) makes it the largest country in Europe.
13,720,000 km2 (5,300,000 sq mi) (98%) of the land area is covered by ice. Though not itself a country, areas are claimed by a number of countries.[Note 2]

Largest English- and largest French-speaking country; largest country completely in the Western Hemisphere by total area (second-largest by land area, after the United States); with the largest surface area of water. Total area and water area figures include area covered by freshwater only and do not include internal waters (non-freshwater) of about 1,600,000 km2, nor territorial waters of 200,000 km2.[4][5]

Second-largest country in Asia (though the largest located wholly within the continent), and second-largest country in the world by land area. Excludes Taiwan, disputed territories with India, and disputed islands in the South China Sea. Figures for total area and water area also exclude all coastal and territorial waters.[Note 3]

Largest English-speaking country and largest in the Western Hemisphere by land area (second-largest by total area, after Canada). Secondary figures for total area and water area include all coastal and territorial waters.[Note 3]
Largest Portuguese-speaking country, largest country in South America and mostly[Note 4] in the Southern Hemisphere, and the largest contiguous territory in the Americas.[11]
Third-largest English-speaking country and largest country in Oceania, largest country without land borders, and the largest country completely in the Southern Hemisphere.[Note 5]
Third-largest country in Asia and largest country in South Asia.[Note 6]
Largest Spanish-speaking country and second-largest country in South America.[Note 7]
Largest landlocked country.[16] Second-largest Russian-speaking country, after Russia, and the largest country in Central Asia. Transcontinental country located between Asia and Europe.
Largest country in Africa; also largest in the Arab world and the Mediterranean Basin.[Note 8]
Second-largest French-speaking country. Largest country in Central and Sub-Saharan Africa. Second-largest country in Africa, has the largest French-speaking city (Kinshasa).
UN figure does not include the entire Kingdom area.
Largest island in the world. Largest territory in the Kingdom of Denmark.
Largest country in Western Asia. Second-largest in the Arab world, after Algeria.
Second-largest Spanish-speaking country by area, after Argentina.
Largest country in Southeast Asia. Largest island country and archipelagic state in the world by area and population.[18]
Third-largest country in Africa and third-largest in the Arab world.[1]
Second-largest landlocked country and largest that does not border a closed sea.
Third-largest Spanish-speaking country and third-largest country in South America.
Third-largest landlocked country and largest outside of Asia.
Transcontinental country located between Asia and Africa.
Transcontinental country located between Asia and Europe.

Figures include metropolitan France (in Europe) as well as the five overseas regions. This does not include New Caledonia (an autonomous sui generis collectivity), the five autonomous overseas collectivities, and the two uninhabited territories (the French Southern and Antarctic Lands and Clipperton Island) which are listed individually, although also part of the French Republic.[Note 16] Third-largest country by European area, and largest within the EU by EU territory.
Second-largest country by European area and largest country wholly in Europe
Metropolitan France (the part of France located in Europe)
Largest country in Southern Europe and second-largest member state of European Union.
Largest country in Northern Europe. Third-largest member state of European Union.
Does not include the disputed Western Sahara, shown separately.[Note 18]
Kingdom of Norway, including Svalbard and Jan Mayen, but excluding Bouvet Island and the Antarctic territorial claims of Queen Maud Land and Peter I Island.[Note 20]
Largest island country in East Asia and the world's 4th largest island country.[Note 21]
Largest country in Central Europe. Before the 1990 German reunification, West Germany was 248,577 (95,976) and East Germany was 108,333 (41,828).
Mainland Norway, excluding Svalbard, Jan Mayen and the dependent territories.[Note 20]
Disputed territory. Administrative control is limited to approximately one-third of this area, with the remaining area controlled by Morocco.
Largest island country in Europe and Western Hemisphere.[Note 26]
Only landlocked country in South East Asia.

Nepal is the largest country in the Himalayan range. The Government of Nepal gives its area as 147,516 square kilometres (56,956 sq mi), which includes an additional 335 square kilometers of disputed territory under Indian administration.[28]
Largest country in the West Indies.
Largest country in Caucasus. Transcontinental country located between Asia and Europe. [Note 32]
The figure shown is for the Republic of Ireland; the island of Ireland is 84,421 km2 or 32,595 sq mi.[31]
Transcontinental country located between Asia and Europe.[Note 33]
Includes Denmark proper only, but excludes the autonomous territories in the Kingdom of Denmark, shown separately.
Includes the special municipalities, but excludes other countries in the Kingdom of the Netherlands, shown separately.[Note 35]
Between 1945 and 1949, the Republic of China included Mainland China, Mongolia, Taiwan and other areas, totaling 11,418,174 km2 (4,408,582 sq mi).[Note 37]
Smallest country in the continental Americas.

Second smallest country in continental Asia.
An American territory, it is the third-largest island of the United States after the Big Island of Hawaii and Kodiak Island of Alaska. Also the smallest part of Hispanic America.
